question.text: A non-conducting ring of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kg</mi></math> and radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math> has a charge <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> uniformly distributed over its circumference. The ring is placed on a rough horizontal surface such that the plane of the ring is parallel to the surface. A vertical magnetic field <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> is switched on at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. At <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> ring starts to rotate about the vertical axis through the centre. The coefficient of friction between the ring and the surface is found to be <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>. Then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math> is

solution.text:
The induced electric field at the periphery of the ring is

E=R2dBdt

⇒E=R212t2=6Rt2

When the ring is about to slip,

qER=μmgR

⇒6qRt2=μmg

⇒μ=6qRt2mg=34=1824

k=18
